acf.intro:
Project Jetson

Welcome to the Project Jetson website.
Jetson is a machine learning-based experiment that provides predictions on the movement(s) of displaced people. This experimental project combines data science, statistical processes, design-thinking techniques, and qualitative research methods. Jetson actively seeks new data sources, new narratives, and new collaborations in order to keep iterating, and improving. It has further underlined the importance of partnership, of collaboration, and of transparency.
acf.first_section:
About the data

The data behind the experiment is central to the overall process. Multiple data inputs are fed into the machine. All data is anonymized and disaggregated per region – and per month. The outcome dataset is a combination of seven years worth of factors that may contribute to forced displacement movement.

Predictors were either suggested by staff within operations and/or refugees themselves. This human-centered approach included focus groups, as well as semi-structured interviews).

The predictor factors are:

  • weather and climate;
  • conflict;
  • market prices;
  • historical population movement patterns (both for internally displaced people and refugees).

Open data is key for the Jetson engine to work. Having technically and legally open data allows humanitarian actors – and others – to make sometimes life-saving decisions to help people, whether those fleeing, or those hosting those who have fled. For example, knowing the number of people arriving at a certain time to a particular region can allow for sufficient preparation, of  for example, contingencies, prepositioning of resources – including human resources. It may also help to identify and attend first to those who are most vulnerable. Jetson represents therefore, a new way of processing and potentially using data. Crucially, it is also an example on how collaboration for open data could potentially, alleviate human suffering and save lives.

The UNHCR Innovation Service wants Project Jetson to become an open process. Creating a functioning prototype that other UNHCR operations and other humanitarian partners could utilize with their own data sets is our version of a fruitful future. For this to be possible, many data sets should be duly processed (e.g. anonymized, cleaned) and openly shared in, ideally, one single data portal. In order to predict, collaboration and partnerships are imperative.  A departure from myopic, territorial approaches of the past, and another step into a future humanitarian response that is multidisciplinary in nature, partnership by default, and whole of society in responsibility and accountability.

Our collaborators and partners:

Our data sources and/or main project partners:

Climate: FAO-SWALIM, WMO, IGAD-ICPAC, UNOSAT, World Bank

Infrastructure: UNOSAT

Conflict: ACLED

Food Security: FAO-FSNAU, FEWES

Population: UNHCR, PRMN

Data Science support: UN Global Pulse, Essex University, Uptake.org

The technology behind:

 

About time series analysis

The experiment consists of measuring multiple data sources and variables to see how changes over time affect the movement of people of concern to UNHCR, particularly refugees and internally displaced people (IDPs). A basic time-series analysis was conducted by machine-learning, in which multiple sources of data/variables are fed into the machine. A time series analysis consists of collecting a series of data points, such as precipitation, changes in markets, and then arranging them with certain time intervals, such as one month, over a period of time. In this case, seven years.

Time series can be analyzed using open source or common statistical commercial software. They are often used by the finance sector, statisticians or econometricians to conduct research. However, for this experiment, we combined time series analysis with machine learning: time series analysis meets computer science.

About machine learning processes:

The machine learning process uses a combination of commonly available commercial software, as well as open source software. Data is fed into the machine, and the machine subsequently attempts to find the best fit, and the best output that explains the behavior of data points that occured in the past, in order to predict the future.

The machine-learning process in this particular experiment has three caveats:

a) the machine does not know the data after either June 2017 or September 2017, and carries out all of its calculations based historical data – without knowing what the actual arrivals were in the subsequent months. This means that the machine was only fed with data until a certain point – even though we had the full dataset until the month in question. We kept this month blank in the machine, in order to serve as a training set. This was done in order to see how well the machine predicted something that already happened, constituting an historical training set.

Additionally, b) the machine is given an algorithm – a formula or a rule – on which to run calculations. However, the algorithm that is given to the machine in order to conduct these calculations does not contain the time variable. Therefore, even though the data is arranged per month, per region, the machine is agnostic of the date, since it is not included in the formula.

The machine then, reads all the data and attempts to find the best fit. These are the best computer-produced models that include all possible data points, and how best they are interrelated to each other. For example, if at a certain point the machine sees more arrivals, it will try to graph how does conflict interrelate with increase in conflict and/or lack of rain. The result of this process are 20 models per region studied, in order to understand the overall region population movement. A total of 380 models were tested in this experiment.

For the model selection, the engine tests all 20 models in a certain month and produces the best examples on which to predict the month. This means that the model that can best predict the arrivals for next month may be the same, but equally could change each month, depending on the region.  

FInally, there c) is a data imputation process behind the engine, conducted automatically by the machine. Imputation means that for any missing value (NA) the machine will carry out an automatic assumption assumption behind the distribution – which means ‘it’ will attempt to calculate the result, even with that missing value, trying to see the interrelation of that missing data value with the other variables that are present.
acf.jetson_models:
About the map

The map was requested by UNHCR’s operation in Somalia as a red-light style of visualization. It portrays the level of critically for movement. Moderate means Jetson is predicting the arrivals of next month within the range of the average arrivals of the past 3 months. High means the machine prediction of arrivals  is higher than the average but less than 100% increase in arrivals, and Critical means is double the average (more than a 100% increase).

About the engine

The graphs above are based on different models that are selected based on seven different statistical or computer-science methods: 1) the best model data that ‘fits’ the historical data (R^2); 2) its mean absolute error (MAE); 3) the multiple imputation by chained equations (MICE) seed value of 50 randomly-selected historical values; 4) the percentage of computer prediction accuracy (ACC); 5) Bayesian information criterion (BIC); Akaike information criterion (AIC) and;  7) a simple pearson correlation coefficient (PCC) for either the past 20 months (ACC/PCC) and/or the overall seven years of data (rest).

The model selection methods mentioned above attempt to measure the accuracy of future predictions, and are the difference between the future predictive arrivals vs. actual arrivals. In short, they describe the margin of error of arrivals provided by the machine vs. reality. For example, the higher the MAE, the less accurate the prediction. R^2 is the value of how close the model is based on historical data. The closer (or fit) the model, the higher the value, with 1.0 being the most ideal fit. Each model will have different results of each of the five measures.
acf.second_section:
Project Jetson Version 1.0

What’s new?

Version 1.0 is the first public version of Jetson. The previous versions focused only on the concept of the predictive analytics engine. This version provides functioning models that predict each regions arrival with between a 60% to 110% accuracy – depending upon the region. The more missing data in a particular region, the less accurate is the machine to calculate results.

In version 1.0, we have improved, and added:

  • Automation processes (back-end);
  • Map with level of criticality of displacement;
  • Included end-user feedback;
  • Github site;
  • And a Communications strategy to share results with the general public.

Design:  Version 1.0 of Jetson provides a lighter, faster, and a simpler user interface with the key focus on predicted monthly arrival figures rather than a simulation of population from previous versions. We need web-based tools and applications to be inclusive, including to those with a lower internet bandwidth.

Automation Process:  50% of processes completed in previous versions of Jetson were done by humans but are now performed automatically, by the machine. Different computer applications combine (see Github), to free up time for further development and expansion of prediction regions. We are still refining the processes to be almost semi-automated. Humans are still required to press the run button to execute the various processes.

We are currently working on:
The next steps for Project Jetson are to improve the software deployment of the service and introduce new prediction regions.

  • With the University of Essex and UNOSAT, we are working on a machine learning-based classification model for climate and conflict variables;
  • Our team aims to have the predictive analytics software as a complete package that can be installed and run locally, by other UNHCR operations or partners.

The eventual complete Jetson package will consist of the following processes:

  • Data collection from multiple online sources;
  • Transforming data into-machine readable formats and pushing it online;
  • Running of the predictive analytics algorithms;
  • Analysing the model’s results;
  • Running the analysed statistical correlations to compare model’s accuracy vs. actual figures;
  • Detecting the arrival range (predicted population arrivals);
  • Deciding on best model according to human decision-making rules;
  • Communicating and visualizing the results for the operation.

The deployable package will also include a model monitoring element that picks the best algorithm for the next month and detects the population arrival range, according to analysed correlations. The arrival range on the website is the result of this process.

The automation effort of all technical processes involved will be continuing, therefore minimising human decision making and ‘interference’ where not relevant. This will leave more resources for the Jetson team to focus on top line decisions for the predicted arrivals and the project in general.

faqs.faq_content:
One of the most pressing challenges for humanitarian agencies in trying to predict population movements is the information gap that exists when people move from one place to another. This is particularly challenging during emergencies when fluid or rapid movements make it challenging for humanitarian actors to track and estimate arrivals, and departures. Consequently, this challenge affects planning, emergency preparedness, funding of assistance, and operational services. The challenge is exacerbated by:

  1. Lack of access to territory: referring to regions with ongoing violent conflict, to occupied territories and/or geographical areas where humanitarian actors are not present or access is denied;
  2. Lack of resources: lack of financial or human resources to deploy enumerators to collect data from specific sources or geographical locations;
  3. Lack of informants: collecting data from specific sources or a particular group can bias the data;
  4. Lack of validation: sometimes information verification is conducted only by participant observation (visual) and/or the data provided by the informants could be partial or inaccurate for diverse number of reasons;
  5. A lack of expertise, experience, tools, techniques, systems. We need to be able to attract and hire those with unique experience into our system in order to take our system forwards. These are typically those with less experience, but with more defined expertise in areas that humanitarian organisations do not currently have, or in some cases, do not even know they require.

faqs.faq_title: What is Jetson technology based on?
faqs.faq_content: On forecasting statistical techniques and open source-based applications for modeling. The scripts and the aggregated and anonymized datasets will be published in UNHCR github once the experiment is finished.

faqs.faq_title: Why aren’t you predicting the entire world?
faqs.faq_content: We are in development stage of the project and looking into adding more regions and situations to the experiment. Each region and country have different elements as predictors, therefore there is a need to collect specific data according to context.

1. The project is focused only in the population flow, both across borders (refugees) and internally (IDPs). This means the main research purpose is to measure changes in the population in an specific period of time (e.g. a month).
  2. There is not one single major cause of forced displacement. There are many causes (variables) and an infinite combination of these variables, along with behavioral human patterns that lead to forced displacement. The objective of the model is not to find the cause (why?) but to explain how are people moving (patterns).
  3. This project attempts to find interesting and meaningful patterns in data by making assumptions from the data our partners are providing, particularly when data is not available, or is incomplete.
  4. Some of the assumptions do not need a model to tell that the assumption is correct. Building a model goes beyond identifying the assumptions’ characteristics (e.g. we do not need a model to know people are forced to flee due to conflict). However, the model attempts to find the best combination that could predict the target variable, in this case: population flow numbers and geographical locations, in an specific period of time.

faqs.faq_title: What are the variables for Jetson?
faqs.faq_content:
• Current number of Persons of Concern (PoC) per region per month
  • Departures number of PoC per region per month
  • Arrivals number of PoC per region per month
  • Number of fatalities per region per month
  • Number of violent conflict incidents per region per month
  • River levels per river per month
  • River discharge per river per month
  • Rainfall average per region per month
  • Water drum price per region per month
  • Local goat Price per region per month

The data behind the engine is anonymized, aggregated per month and per region and complies with UNHCR Data Protection policy standards

The models used for each region in the engine represent the top 3 best ‘fit’ functions that can explain the behaviour of seven years of historical data. The target variable (y) is number of arrivals for each region.

The model is trained with data until 30 June 2017 and the date that the predictive algorithm was built is 1 September 2017.

Project Jetson is a predictive analytics project aimed at providing predictions on the movement of displaced populations within and outside of Somalia. It’s a project initiated and launched by UNHCR’s Innovation Service. The purpose of this website is to contribute to the sharing knowledge, including lessons learned, and mistakes/failures within humanitarian innovation and beyond – in this case on the topic of data. The information shown on this site should be viewed as an indication of potential movement(s), and possible underlying causes. UNHCR does not represent or endorse the accuracy or reliability of any advice, opinion, or analysis developed as a result of the use of predictions data provided on this website. acf.third_section:
A final note on Jetson, and its future

Jetson is only possible because managers provide, and actively encourage experimental approaches. Jetson is only possible because we can attract, and hopefully retain talent that brings a unique, diversity of thought and experience. Jetson is only possible because inclusive design, validation, and iteration processes have been embraced. Jetson is only possible because of an active pursuance of partnership. The future of of Jetson will also require an ability to scale, and to embrace decision making that is based on data and evidence. That requires us to make Jetson more accessible, better understood, and useable, in some case by people whom this will be uncomfortable for. More on this later.
